Authors: Romano Ph.
Title: The elderly patient with multiple injuries. Experience of the Anesthesiology Department of the Henri Mondor Hospital; [LE POLYTRAUMATISE AGE. EXPERIENCE DU SERVICE DE REANIMATION CHIRURGICALE ET TRAUMATOLOGIQUE DE L'HOPITAL HENRI MONDOR A CRETEIL]
Affiliations: France
Authors with affiliations: Romano Ph., France
Abstract: 72 elderly patients with multiple injuries, 42 women, aged between 60 and 86 yr and 30 men, aged between 60 and 78 yr (median age 68 1/2) are described. These cases included 2 work accidents, (fall from scaffolding) 5 suicide attempts, including 4 deliberate falls of 4 to 8 meters and one fall under a train, the 65 others were road accidents: 24 pedestrians, 2 cyclists, 9 passengers of light vehicles and 2 motocyclists (63 and 69 yr), 28 victims of various road accidents. 22% of the patients died within 24 hr, 24% within the first 4 days, 72% died within 10 days. Only 29% survived one month after the accident. The association of cranial injury, thoracic and abdominal injury was particularly dangerous and accounted for 85% of death. It is concluded that elderly polytraumatized patients should be treated on intensive care units where various surgical specialists are available.
Index Keywords: Abdominal Injuries; Aged; Anesthesia; Craniocerebral Trauma; English Abstract; Female; France; Human; Intensive Care Units; Male; Middle Age; Prognosis; Retrospective Studies; Thoracic Injuries; Wounds and Injuries; aged; geriatrics; intensive care; major clinical study; multiple trauma; therapy; abdominal injury; adult; anesthesia; article; female; France; head injury; human; injury; intensive care unit; male; mortality; prognosis; retrospective study; thorax injury; utilization review

Authors: Brouns F.; Saris W.H.M.; Stroecken J.; Beckers E.; Thijssen R.; Rehrer N.J.; Ten Hoor F.
Title: Eating, drinking, and cycling. A controlled Tour de France simulation study, Part II. Effect of diet manipulation
Affiliations: Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Brouns F., Netherlands; Saris W.H.M., Netherlands; Stroecken J., Netherlands; Beckers E., Netherlands; Thijssen R., Netherlands; Rehrer N.J., Netherlands; Ten Hoor F., Netherlands
Abstract: Field studies during the Tour de France indicated that cylists consume 30% of daily energy intake as liquid carbohydrate (CHO)-enriched nutrition with the goal of maintaining energy and CHO balance. The aim of the present investigation was to study the effect of such dietary manipulation during 2 days of long-lasting exhausting cycling on food and fluid intake, energy balance, nitrogen balance, and nutrient oxidation. Thirteen highly trained cyclists were divided into two subgroups receiving ad libitum either a primarily maltodextrin-based beverage (Mf) (20% w/v, 85% maltodextrin, 15% fructose) or a 50/50% composed fructose-maltodextrin (FM) beverage in addition to their normal diet. The study was performed during a 7-day stay in a respiration chamber (2 preparation days, 1 standardized resting day, 2 cycling days, 1.5 standardized recovery days), allowing for continuous gas analysis, weighed food and fluid intake procedure, and collection of excretes. The data of this study were compared with data from the same subjects receiving a normal CHO-rich diet (N) (60 En%) in a separate experiment. The results showed that the cyclists receiving Mf were able to maintain EB during sustained exercise days in contrast to when receiving N and to subjects receiving FM. With Mf treatment CHO intake increased, up to 80 En% (17.5 ± 1.0 g·kg-1 BW) and carbohydrate balance remained positive. The subjects receiving FM had the largest CHO oxidation, calculated from R. Protein oxidation significantly increased in N and FM as a result of exercise but not in Mf. The latter subjects were in slightly negative nitrogen balance at a protein intake level of 1.4 g·kg-1 BW. The results show that supplementation with maltodextrin beverages is an adequate measure to maintain EB and CHO balance and furthermore that increased CHO intake induces protein sparing. The protein requirement while being in energy and carbohydrate balance during days of sustained exhausting cycling was in the range of 1.5-1.8 g·kg-1 BW.
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; adult; caloric intake; controlled study; cycling; diet; energy balance; fluid intake; human; male; nitrogen balance; normal human; nutrition

Authors: Lucía A.; Hoyos J.; Carvajal A.; Chicharro J.L.
Title: Heart rate response to professional road cycling: The tour de france
Affiliations: Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Esc. de Enfermeria, F., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, E-28040 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Lucía A., Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Hoyos J.; Carvajal A., Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Chicharro J.L., Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Madrid, Spain, Esc. de Enfermeria, F., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, E-28040 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The aim of the present investigation was to evaluate the heart rate response of 8 professional cyclists (26 ± 3 yr; 68.9 ± 5.2 kg; V̇O2max: 74.0 ± 5.8 ml.kg-1.min-1) during the 3-week Tour de France as an indicator of exercise intensity. Subjects wore a heart rate telemeter during 22 competition stages and recorded data were analysed using computer software. Two reference heart rates (corresponding to the first and second ventilatory thresholds or VT1 and VT2) were used to establish three levels of exercise intensity defined as phases I (< VT1), II (VT1 -VT2) and III (< VT2). The average total time spent by each subject in each of the 3 phases respectively was approximately 71, 23 and 8 h. The relative contributions of each phase were 70, 23 and 7%. The percentage relative contribution of each phase was significantly different (p < 0.01) in each of the competition stages (time trials, flat stages, 'high-mountain' stages and 'medium-mountain' stages). Exercise intensity was particularly high during the time trials and high mountain stages. It may be concluded that during an endurance event such as the Tour de France, although the overall contribution of moderate (VT1 to VT2) or high intensity exercise (> VT2) is substantially lower than that of light, aerobic exercise (< VT1), a clear distinction must be made between the different type of stages (i.e. easy, flat parcours vs mountain stages or time trials) and the role of each cyclist in the team must be also considered.
Author Keywords: Cycling; Heart rate; Physiology; Ventilatory threshold
Index Keywords: adult; article; computer program; cycling; exercise; heart rate; human; male; normal human; telemetry

Authors: Lepoutre R.; Gounelle De Pontanel H.; Lafarge J.P.
Author full names: Lepoutre, R. (57189556897); Gounelle De Pontanel, H. (7005781212); Lafarge, J.P. (6602320434)
Title: Sport doping: From 'vitaminic impregnation' to 'biologic preparation'; [DOPAGE: DE L'IMPREGNATION VITAMINIQUE A LA PREPARATION BIOLOGIQUE]
Abstract: Sportsmen do use doping; nobody can ignore it any longer. Throughout 1978 up to 1079 the press has never ceased to draw attention to it, sometimes treating the problem in very downright terms. After the exclusion of the cyclist Michel Pollentier from the Tour de France the revelations went on from those about four medallists in the European athletics championship to Bernhard Thevenet, not to mention the statements of Renate Neufeld, from Eastern Germany who defected to the West, and unveiled the systemization of the use of medical preparatives in the East. The Academy of Medicine, shocked by this situation, constituted a working group that was given the task of evaluating its extent and determining its nature.
Index Keywords: athlete; doping; human cell; performance; prevention; short survey; sports medicine

Authors: Desbordes M.
Author full names: Desbordes, Michel (36843433200)
Title: Empirical analysis of the innovation phenomena in the sports equipment industry
Affiliations: Université Paris Sud-XI, Division STAPS, Orsay cedex 91405, Bâtiment 335, France
Authors with affiliations: Desbordes M., Université Paris Sud-XI, Division STAPS, Orsay cedex 91405, Bâtiment 335, France
Abstract: This article presents the results of a survey conducted in 108 firms in the French sports industry. The inquiry was based on three main themes: research & development, innovation and adoption of new materials. The study has shown a link between the product's life cycle and the structure of the industry. In fact the various levels of achievements reached by sports products have generated various structures among the sectors already mentioned. Slightly declining sectors, like skiing or yachting, are rather concentrated and tend to focus on process innovations. Fast expanding sectors, like snowboard, mountain bike and cycling, are rather atomized and innovate much more on new product and materials.
Index Keywords: France; innovation; manufacturing; research and development; sport

Authors: Butryn T.M.; Masucci M.A.
Author full names: Butryn, Ted M. (6507162915); Masucci, Matthew A. (35173517600)
Title: It's not about the book: A Cyborg Counternarrative of Lance Armstrong
Affiliations: San Jose State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Butryn T.M., San Jose State University, United States; Masucci M.A., San Jose State University, United States
Abstract: In his autobiography, It's Not About the Bike: My Journey Back to Life, Lance Armstrong claimed that his identity as a human being is not defined simply in terms of his skill at racing a bicycle. Armstrong's articulation of multiple, competing identifications is consistent with a postmodern notion of fractured, incomplete identity. However, following Butler, identity can be seen as contested, negotiated, and often hegemonic. Drawing from the emerging field of cyborgology, and the work of Birrell and McDonald, the authors construct a parallel cyborg “counternarrative” alongside the popular Armstrong story. By interrogating Armstrong's story through the lens of cyborg theory, the authors will explore and articulate alternative meanings/readings of Armstrong's narrative of self as represented in his book and, finally, suggest that Armstrong's story can be read as an exemplar of the postmodern cyborg sporting hero. © 2003, SAGE Publications. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cyborg theory; Lance Armstrong; sport heroes; sport technology; Tour de France

Authors: Ameratunga S.N.; Alexander C.S.; Smith G.S.; Lennon D.R.; Norton R.N.
Author full names: Ameratunga, Shanthi N. (6701716378); Alexander, Cheryl S. (7202287412); Smith, Gordon S. (7406738484); Lennon, Diana R. (7006501381); Norton, Robyn N. (56253453500)
Title: Trauma-related hospitalizations among urban adolescents in New Zealand: Priorities for prevention
Affiliations: Injury Prevention Research Centre, Dept. Comm. Hlth., Univ. of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Injury Prevention Research Centre, Dept. of Pediat., Univ. of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Ctr. Adol. Hlth. Prom. Dis. Prev., Johns Hopkins Sch. of Public Health, Baltimore, MD, United States; Ctr. for Injury Research and Policy, Johns Hopkins Sch. of Public Health, Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ameratunga S.N., Injury Prevention Research Centre, Dept. Comm. Hlth., Univ. of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Alexander C.S., Ctr. Adol. Hlth. Prom. Dis. Prev., Johns Hopkins Sch. of Public Health, Baltimore, MD, United States; Smith G.S., Ctr. for Injury Research and Policy, Johns Hopkins Sch. of Public Health, Baltimore, MD, United States; Lennon D.R., Injury Prevention Research Centre, Dept. of Pediat., Univ. of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Norton R.N., Injury Prevention Research Centre, Dept. Comm. Hlth., Univ. of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: Purpose: To: (a) determine the magnitude, characteristics, and in- patient costs of injury among hospitalized urban adolescents in New Zealand (NZ); (b) identify regional priorities for injury prevention and investigative research; and (c) compare the study findings with published data from other industrialized countries. Methods: The 1989-1993 files of the NZ Hospital Discharge Database were accessed to identify and analyze trauma- related admissions of adolescents residing in NZ's largest metropolitan region. Results: The estimated 9569 hospitalizations for injury accounted for one-fourth of all adolescent admissions in the region, a mean annual hospitalization rate of 1292/100,000 population and a minimum annual cost of NZ $5.8 million for in-patient care. Males and indigenous Maori youth had comparatively higher rates of hospitalizations for most major causes of injury. Falls, pedal cyclist injury, cuts, and piercing injuries were leading causes of hospitalization for trauma in early adolescence. Admission rates for motorcylist and other motor vehicle occupant trauma and self-inflicted injury increased substantially among older adolescents. Sport and recreational activities comprised at least one-sixth of injury admissions. Conclusions: The overall rates of injury resulting in hospitalization among Auckland adolescents were comparable to those reported from Australia and France, but higher than those from the United States, Canada, and Israel. By identifying priority issues and high-risk groups, this study provides a foundation for regional injury control initiatives. It also demonstrates the utility and limitations of E-coded hospital discharge registries in defining the burden of serious nonfatal trauma.
Author Keywords: Adolescents; E-code; Epidemiology; Gender differences; Hospitalization; Injury; New Zealand; Urban

Authors: Mestre-Gonguet C.
Author full names: Mestre-Gonguet, Catherine (6507973671)
Title: Road cycling in the Hautes-Alpes (France): Shared itineraries for cars and bicycles; [Le vélo routier dans le département des Hautes-Alpes (France): Les itinéraires partagés]
Affiliations: Sainte-Marguerite, La Garde 83130, 206 Rue Forbin, France
Authors with affiliations: Mestre-Gonguet C., Sainte-Marguerite, La Garde 83130, 206 Rue Forbin, France
Abstract: As part of its tourism development scheme, the French Hautes-Alpes department aims to develop cycling on its road network. Many famous cycling itineraries use the mountain roads of this region to reach some of the most famous passes in cycling history. With the development of shared itineraries, the local authorities are trying to encourage the various road users to coexist peaceably and to attract cyclists to roads with lighter traffic. The study asks whether such measures will help to lengthen the tourist season and to spread tourism more evenly across the region.
Author Keywords: Bicycle; Cycling routes; Hautes-Alpes; Tourist flows

Authors: Laumon B.; Martin J.L.
Title: Analysis of biases in epidemiological knowledge of road accidents in France; [Analyse des biais dans la connaissance épidémiologique des accidents de la route en France]
Source title: Revue d'Epidemiologie et de Sante Publique
Affiliations: INRETS/UCBL UMRETTE, F-69675 Bron Cedex, 25, avenue Francois-Mitterrand, France
Authors with affiliations: Laumon B., INRETS/UCBL UMRETTE, F-69675 Bron Cedex, 25, avenue Francois-Mitterrand, France; Martin J.L., INRETS/UCBL UMRETTE, F-69675 Bron Cedex, 25, avenue Francois-Mitterrand, France
Abstract: Background: In France, as in many countries, road casualty statistics are mostly based on police reports. It is generally recognized that these data are incomplete but no measurement has been made of the degree of under-reporting and thus of associated biases. This study aims to demonstrate and quantify these biases. Methods: The study compares, after data linkage, the 10 202 people reported injured or killed in 1996 in the medical road accident victims Register in the Département du Rhône (France), with the 4 572 victims reported by the police during the same year and in the same area. This Département was chosen, as it is the only region in France where these two independent data sources coexist. Two types of possible biases are studied: injury severity classification bias and selection bias induced by underreporting. Results: The study shows that the definition of "serious injury" used by the police exaggerates the severity of the victim's condition in over half the cases. This bias depends on road user group. This bias is maximum for pedestrians: compared to a slightly injured car occupant, a pedestrian with the same injury severity level has significantly more chance to be considered as severely injured (RR=1.78; 95% CI: 1.11-2.87). Conversely, significant selection biases are related to data collection by the police. The multivariate analysis shows that the underreporting of victims increases if no third party is involved (i.e. without any other vehicle or pedestrian), and reduces with injury severity. It also varies by road user group (with the largest underreporting for cyclists). Among the most seriously injured in accidents involving third parties, motor cyclists and car users are the most reported category and pedestrians the least (RR=0.80; 95% CI: 0.70-0.92). Biases in Register selection are much more limited and basically concern underreporting of victims of minor accidents who did not require medical care. Conclusions: This study confirms and quantifies misleading distortions in police statistics used to assess road accidents. These results concern the relevant indicators to be used to define road safety issues.
Author Keywords: Abbreviated injury scale; Bias (Epidemiology); France; Medical record linkage; Multivariate analysis; Traffic accidents

Title: Physiological differences and rating of perceived exertion (RPE) in profesional, amateur and young cyclists; [Diferencias fisiológicas y de percepción subjetiva de fatiga (RPE), en ciclistas profesionales, aficionados y juveniles]
Affiliations: Fund. Deportiva Munic. de Aviles, Departamento de Medicina Deportiva, 33400 Avilés, Asturias, C/Del Fuero de Avilés s/n, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Pérez-Landaluce López J., Fund. Deportiva Munic. de Aviles, Departamento de Medicina Deportiva, 33400 Avilés, Asturias, C/Del Fuero de Avilés s/n, Spain; Fernández García B., Fund. Deportiva Munic. de Aviles, Departamento de Medicina Deportiva, 33400 Avilés, Asturias, C/Del Fuero de Avilés s/n, Spain; Rodríguez-Alonso M., Fund. Deportiva Munic. de Aviles, Departamento de Medicina Deportiva, 33400 Avilés, Asturias, C/Del Fuero de Avilés s/n, Spain; Terrados Cepeda N., Fund. Deportiva Munic. de Aviles, Departamento de Medicina Deportiva, 33400 Avilés, Asturias, C/Del Fuero de Avilés s/n, Spain
Abstract: The aim of this study is to measure the physiological characteristics and the rating of perceived exertion (RPE) in 72 high level road cyclists. Methods: The cyclists are divided into three groups according to their age and sports category (24 are professional, 22 amateur and 26 junior). They carried out a progressive test to exhaustion on a specific cycloergometer (Orion. France), starting at a power output of 100 watts and increasing 50 watts every four minutes. VO2 was measured breath by breath by a metabolimeter (V max 29, Sensor Medics USA). At the end of each of the four minute steps the subject is asked about his RPE using the 6-20 Borg scale. Results: Professional cyclists showed VO2 max, VO2/kg. and maximum power output significantly higher than the other groups, while there are no significantly differences between amateurs and juniors. VO2 max and RPE are significantly different, in all the categories, at high loads. No significant differences are found between RPE and %VO2 max. RPE and heart rate (HR) are significantly different between professionals and juniors. RPE and %FC max are significantly different with low loads, but not at high loads. In the same way, RPE/w and RPE(w/kg) are significantly different in all categories. Conclusions: We conclude that professional road cyclists reached greater VO2 max, VO2 max/kg and maximum power higher than the other categories. So, therefore these parameters are therefore good as performance indicators. By means of the rating of perceived exertion we can prescribe the exercise intensity in each category. The RPE is a valid method for the regulation of exercise intensity in high level cycling, although different categories and age must be borne in mind, as it is not possible to compare the data of groups of high level cyclists with those who have a lower sports level.

Authors: Lucia A.; Earnest C.; Arribas C.
Author full names: Lucia, Alejandro (7102180908); Earnest, Conrad (7003778626); Arribas, Carlos (36790934800)
Title: The Tour de France: A physiological review
Source title: Scandinavian Journal of Medicine and Science in Sports
Affiliations: Fac. Cie. Actividad Fis. el Deporte, Universidad Europea de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Cooper Inst. Ctr. Hum. Perf. Nutr., Dallas, TX, United States; Diario El País, Madrid, Spain; Pabellón Polideportivo, Universidad Europea de Madrid, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Lucia A., Fac. Cie. Actividad Fis. el Deporte, Universidad Europea de Madrid, Madrid, Spain, Pabellón Polideportivo, Universidad Europea de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Earnest C., Cooper Inst. Ctr. Hum. Perf. Nutr., Dallas, TX, United States; Arribas C., Diario El País, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: On 5 July 2003, the Tour de France (TDF) has celebrated 100th running. Instead of a chimney sweep competing during his free time (as in 1903), the recent winner is a highly trained, professional cyclist whose entire life-style has been dedicated to reach his pinnacle during this event. The TDF has been held successfully for 100 years, but the application of the physiologic sciences to the sport is a relatively recent phenomenon. Although some historical reports help to understand the unique physiological characteristics of this race, scientific studies were not available in Sports Science/ Applied Physiology journals until the 1990s. The aim of this article is to review the history of the TDF. Special emphasis is placed on the last decade where classic physiology has been integrated into applied scientific cycling data.
Author Keywords: Endurance exercise; Physiology; Professional cycling
Index Keywords: Bicycling; Cardiovascular Physiology; Competitive Behavior; Doping in Sports; France; Humans; Male; Nutrition Physiology; Physical Education and Training; Physical Endurance; anthropometry; athlete; competition; cycling; data analysis; demography; history of medicine; human; hydration; lifestyle; literature; nutrition; review; sport; sports medicine

Authors: Rumeau Rouquette C.; Francillard V.
Author full names: Rumeau Rouquette, C. (7006393538); Francillard, V. (6504406097)
Title: Epidemiology of accidents in children and youth; [LES ACCIDENTS CHEZ L'ENFANT ET LE JEUNE DONNEES EPIDEMIOLOGIQUES]
Affiliations: France
Authors with affiliations: Rumeau Rouquette C., France; Francillard V., France
Abstract: France is among the European countries which have the highest death rate due to accidents in children from 0 to 4 years of age and in youths from 15 to 24 years of age. Furthermore, from the age of 5 onwards, accidents account for approximately 50% of deaths. This illustrates the absolute necessity for effective prevention which should be applied to all causes of accidents and above all road accidents which alone account for approximately 50% of accidental deaths with marked predominance for male subjects. Child pedestrians are often involved in accidents at a very young age (108 deaths from 0 to 4 years of age among boys and 52 among girls). These figures exceed those for adults whereas young children are less often compelled to travel on foot. These accidents are therefore due to poor supervision. Between the ages of 5 and 9, the situation is worse and accidents involving pedestrians in this age group are more common than in any other. Specific steps should be taken to ensure safety both on the way to school and elsewhere, and it should be strictly forbidden for children to play on the street. Child cyclists begin to be involved in accidents towards the age of 5 years but the highest incidence occurs in the 10 to 14 year old age group since it is in this age group that fully one quarter of all bicycle accidents occur. Should it not be necessary to introduce strict control and some form of training at school? Adolescents who ride motorcycles or drive cars run an extremely serious risk: 22,000 dead and seriously injured between the ages of 15 and 19 in 1972. The problem cannot be solved simply through individual efforts but must be approached in depth, considering all its sociological and psychological implications.
Index Keywords: accident; age; child; childhood; epidemiology; injury; mortality; statistics; traffic accident

Authors: Lucia A.; Hoyos J.; Chicharro J.L.
Title: Physiology of professional road cycling
Affiliations: Department of Anatomy and Physiology, European University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Exercise Physiology Research Unit, Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Lucia A., Department of Anatomy and Physiology, European University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Hoyos J., Exercise Physiology Research Unit, Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Chicharro J.L., Exercise Physiology Research Unit, Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Professional road cycling is an extreme endurance sport. Approximately 30 000 to 35 000km are cycled each year in training and competition and some races, such as the Tour de France last 21 days (∼ 100 hours of competition) during which professional cyclists (PC) must cover >3500km. In some phases of such a demanding sport, on the other hand, exercise intensity is surprisingly high, since PC must complete prolonged periods of exercise (i.e. time trials, high mountain ascents) at high percentages (∼90%) of maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max) [above the anaerobic threshold (AT)]. Although numerous studies have analysed the physiological responses of elite, amateur level road cyclists during the last 2 decades, their findings might not be directly extrapolated to professional cycling. Several studies have recently shown that PC exhibit some remarkable physiological responses and adaptations such as: an efficient respiratory system (i.e. lack of 'tachypnoeic shift' at high exercise intensities); a considerable reliance on fat metabolism even at high power outputs; or several neuromuscular adaptations (i.e. a great resistance to fatigue of slow motor units). This article extensively reviews the different responses and adaptations (cardiopulmonary system, metabolism, neuromuscular factors or endocrine system) to this sport. A special emphasis is placed on the evaluation of performance both in the laboratory (i.e. the controversial Conconi test, distinction between climbing and time trial ability, etc.) and during actual competitions such as the Tour de France.
Index Keywords: adaptation; anaerobic threshold; anthropometry; cardiovascular response; cycling; endocrine system; endurance; feeding behavior; heart rate; hematology; hyperventilation; hypocapnia; neuromuscular system; oxygen consumption; review; sports medicine; training

Authors: Abergel E.; Linhart A.; Chatellier G.; Gariepy J.; Ducardonnet A.; Diebold B.; Menard J.
Title: Vascular and cardiac remodeling in world class professional cyclists
Affiliations: Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France
Authors with affiliations: Abergel E., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Linhart A., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Chatellier G., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Gariepy J., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Ducardonnet A., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Diebold B., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France; Menard J., Ctr. Med. Prev. Cardio-Vasc. (Med 9), Hopital Broussais, 75674 Paris Cedex 14, 96 rue Didot, France
Abstract: Background: Numerous studies have demonstrated that left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy is often associated with conditioning. Methods and Results: The aim of the study was to evaluate cardiac and carotid artery changes induced by professional cycling. We collected M-mode left ventricle and B- mode right common carotid artery data from 149 male professional cyclists before the 1995 'Tour de France' race and 52 male control subjects. LV mass indexed to body surface area in cyclists was double that in control subjects, with no overlap of 95% confidence intervals (cyclists 100.9 to 187 g/m2 and control subjects 51.8 to 96.3 g/m2). Both mean arterial diameter and mean arterial diastolic intima-media thickness (IMT) were 13% higher in cyclists than in control subjects, with overlap of 95% confidence intervals (for arterial IMT 0.45 to 0.65 mm in cyclists and 0.38 to 0.60 mm in control subjects). Conclusions: Our results suggest that intense cycling has an effect on the cardiovascular system, more pronounced on the left ventricle and less pronounced on large arteries. Nevertheless, athletic training should be considered as a potential determinant of carotid modification.
Index Keywords: adult; artery diameter; article; athlete; B scan; carotid artery disease; clinical article; cycling; echocardiography; endurance; heart left ventricle function; heart ventricle remodeling; human; male; priority journal; risk factor; training

Authors: Dawson D.
Title: Trend toward lightweight carbon bikes is a winner
Abstract: The cycles that Lance Armstrong pedalled to victory in the Tour de France in 1999 and 2000 were stock bikes built by Trek Inc. The bikes were built around a light-weight all carbon composite frame. The carbon/epoxy frame is constructed from hollow tubes and connectors using a composite manufacturing process designed and patented by Radius Engineering. The frames weight can be reduced further by using a lighter carbon fibre in its construction. Carbon is a good material for bicycle construction because it is lightweight and also because it adsorbs shock and is therefore easier on the body and relieves fatigue.
Index Keywords: bicycle frame; carbon fiber; fiber reinforced composite; weight

Authors: Saris W.H.; Schrijver J.; van Erp Baart M.A.; Brouns F.
Title: Adequacy of vitamin supply under maximal sustained workloads: the Tour de France.
Source title: International journal for vitamin and nutrition research. Supplement = Internationale Zeitschrift fur Vitamin- und Ernahrungsforschung. Supplement
Abstract: In the Tour de France competing cyclists must pedal about 4000 km over a period of three weeks with only one day allowed for rest. The course includes 30 mountains, the highest of which reaches an altitude of approximately 2700 m. The energy expenditure values of these cyclists range from a mean of 25.4 MJ/day to peak values of 32.7 MJ/day. These are the highest values that have ever been reported for a period longer than seven days. On the basis of the food records of 5 cyclists, it turned out that 62 En.% is derived from CHO, 15 En.% from protein, and 23 En.% from fat. Since the food choice is primarily focused on digestibility and energy content, this results in a frequent consumption of sweet cakes and CHO-rich fluids. Some 49% of the energy is consumed in between meals. Such a nutritional pattern leads to a lowering of the nutrient density especially with respect to the B-vitamins. Intake of vitamins B1, B2, B6, and C, including contribution from enriched sport drinks, was 1.97 mg, 4.96 mg, 2.40 mg, and 158 mg, respectively. Besides this, intramuscular injections of megadosis vitamins of B1, B2, B6, nicotinamide, pantothenic acid, and especially B12 did increase the intake drastically. This was reflected in high blood concentrations of vitamins. Except for folic acid, vitamins (B1, B2, B6, and B12) exceeded the upper limits of the values from a reference group, particularly B12, which exceeded the reference values by up to 400%. During the Tour, vitamin concentrations remained essentially unchanged.
Index Keywords: Bicycling; Energy Metabolism; Food, Fortified; Human; Male; Physical Endurance; Vitamins; vitamin; bicycle; diet supplementation; energy metabolism; human; male; physical stress; review
Abbreviated Source Title: Int J Vitam Nutr Res Suppl
